citation.article-title: Anaerobic degradation of indolic compounds by sulfate-reducing enrichment cultures, and description of Desulfobacterium indolicum gen. nov. spec. nov.

p.s: Description of Desulfobacterium indolicum sp. nov.
Desulfobacterium indolicum (In.do'li.cum. M.L. adj. indolicum pertaining to,indole. Desulfobacterium indolicum a sulfate-reducing bacterium oxidizing indole.)
Oval to rod-shaped cells of varying size, 0.7-1.5 μm in diameter, and 2-2.5 μm in length.
Cells grown on indole are often larger than those grown on other compounds and may be pleomorphic.
At concentrations higher than 1,5 mmol/l, indole is toxic, and for cultivation it should be added repeatedly in smaller amounts.
Slow growth occurs on formate, acetate, propionate, ethanol, propanol, butanol, pyruvate, malate, fumarate, maleinate, succinate, anthranitate, and quinoline.
Vitamin B12 , and NaCl and MgCl2 ⋄ 6H2O at concentrations of 20 g/l and 3 g/l, respectively, are required for growth.
DNA base ratio: 47.4 mol% G + C (thermal denaturation).
D. indolicum has been enriched and isolated so far only from marine sediments.
Type strain: In04, DSM number 3383, deposited in the Deutsche Sammlung yon Mikroorganismen.
